bacterial_panicle_blight.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
bacterial_panicle_blight.method: Foliar spray during early boot stage
bacterial_panicle_blight.availability: Widely available at agro-shops across dry and intermediate zones
bacterial_panicle_blight.note: Avoid use in copper-sensitive soils. Do not mix with acidic pesticides.

bacterial_panicle_blight.name: Streptomycin Sulphate 17% WP
bacterial_panicle_blight.method: Spray at panicle initiation if symptoms appear
bacterial_panicle_blight.availability: Available in larger agro outlets; limited stock in rural areas
bacterial_panicle_blight.note: Use with caution – antibiotic resistance is a concern. Not for organic farming.

downey_mildew.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
downey_mildew.method: Spray before expected rainfall or humidity spikes
downey_mildew.frequency: Apply every 7–10 days during high-risk periods
downey_mildew.note: Preventive use is key. Apply early; ineffective on advanced infections.

downey_mildew.name: Metalaxyl 8% + Mancozeb 64% WP
downey_mildew.method: Foliar spray at first sign of white downy growth
downey_mildew.frequency: One application, repeat only if needed after 10 days
downey_mildew.availability: Available in major towns and agricultural supply centers
downey_mildew.note: More effective than Mancozeb alone, but higher cost. Use sparingly to prevent resistance.

dead_heart.name: Chlorpyrifos 20% EC
dead_heart.method: Spray during evening to target stem borer moths
dead_heart.frequency: One application at early infestation, monitor after 7 days
dead_heart.availability: Widely available but under regulatory review due to toxicity
dead_heart.note: Highly toxic. Wear full PPE. Avoid spraying near water bodies.

dead_heart.name: Quinalphos 25% EC
dead_heart.method: Spray during late evening; focus on plant base
dead_heart.note: Effective against early larval stages. Avoid use during flowering.

bacterial_leaf_blight.name: Copper Hydroxide 77% WP
bacterial_leaf_blight.method: Foliar spray at first appearance of V-shaped lesions
bacterial_leaf_blight.frequency: One to two sprays, 7 days apart
bacterial_leaf_blight.availability: Common in wet and dry zone agro-shops
bacterial_leaf_blight.note: Best used preventively. Do not exceed recommended dose to avoid phytotoxicity.

bacterial_leaf_blight.name: Kasugamycin 5% WP
bacterial_leaf_blight.method: Spray during early boot stage if disease pressure is high
bacterial_leaf_blight.note: Highly effective but expensive. Recommended for high-value crops or severe outbreaks.

brown_spot.name: Tricyclazole 75% WP
brown_spot.method: Spray at booting or early flowering stage
brown_spot.note: Also effective against blast. Ideal for preventive use in high-humidity areas.

brown_spot.name: Isoprothiolane 40% EC
brown_spot.method: Foliar spray during grain filling stage
brown_spot.availability: Moderate availability; more common in commercial farming regions
brown_spot.note: Provides long-lasting protection. Compatible with integrated pest management (IPM).

hispa.name: Chlorpyrifos 20% EC
hispa.method: Spray upper leaf surfaces thoroughly in evening
hispa.frequency: One spray if infestation is moderate
hispa.note: Hispa beetles are active during day; evening spray increases contact kill.

hispa.name: Quinalphos 25% EC
hispa.method: Spray at early morning or late evening
hispa.note: Rotate with other chemicals to prevent resistance development.

tungro.name: Imidacloprid 17.8% SL
tungro.method: Soil drench or early foliar spray to control green leafhoppers
tungro.frequency: Apply at nursery stage and transplanting
tungro.note: Most effective when applied early. Protects young plants from vector transmission.

tungro.name: Imidacloprid 200g/l SL
tungro.method: Treat the nursery and continue spraying at 10-14 day intervals if symptoms appear.
tungro.note: Effective for Thrips and Brown plant hoppers, which can be vectors for viruses. [1]

tungro.name: Thiamethoxam 25% WG
tungro.method: Seed treatment or early foliar spray
tungro.availability: Available in urban and semi-urban agro stores
tungro.note: Excellent for vector control. Avoid overuse to protect beneficial insects.

blast.name: Tricyclazole 75% WP
blast.method: Spray at booting stage – critical for neck blast prevention
blast.frequency: One preventive spray is usually sufficient
blast.availability: Highly recommended and stocked in blast-prone areas
blast.note: Do not wait for symptoms. Proactive spraying is most effective.

blast.name: Isoprothiolane 40% EC
blast.note: Long residual activity. Good alternative to rotate with Tricyclazole.

bacterial_leaf_streak.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
bacterial_leaf_streak.method: Foliar spray at early symptom stage
bacterial_leaf_streak.frequency: One to two sprays, 7 days apart
bacterial_leaf_streak.note: Best used preventively during rainy seasons when disease spreads via water splash.

bacterial_leaf_streak.name: Kasugamycin 5% WP
bacterial_leaf_streak.method: Spray during boot stage if disease pressure is high
bacterial_leaf_streak.note: Highly effective but costly. Use only in severe cases or seed multiplication fields.

sheath_blight.name: Hexaconazole 50G/L EC
sheath_blight.frequency: Apply when disease spread is fast
sheath_blight.note: Source: Department of Agriculture, Sri Lanka. [2]

sheath_blight.name: Propiconazole 250 G/L EC
sheath_blight.frequency: Apply when disease spread is fast
sheath_blight.note: Source: Department of Agriculture, Sri Lanka. [2]

sheath_blight.name: Tebuconazole 250g/l EC
sheath_blight.frequency: Apply when disease spread is fast
sheath_blight.note: Source: Department of Agriculture, Sri Lanka. [2]

brown_plant_hopper.name: Fipronil 50g/l SC
brown_plant_hopper.note: Also effective for Thrips and Leaf Folder in Paddy. [3]
